author: By David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt
title: U.S. Seeks Delay in Gaza Ground Invasion to Put Air Defenses in Place
description: The systems would allow the United States to provide more protection for American troops at bases in Iraq, Syria and elsewhere.
content: The Biden administration has asked Israel to delay a ground invasion of Gaza for a few days to give the United States more time to put air defense batteries, fighter planes and other military assets in place to protect American troops, U.S. officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Thursday Briefing: Gaza Is Running Out of Fuel
description: Plus Vietnam’s many cable cars.
content: The humanitarian crisis in Gaza deepened yesterday as Israel said it had conducted “wide-scale” strikes and again warned residents in Gaza to flee south ahead of a possible invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana G. Smith
title: An R.S.V. Shot for Infants Is in Short Supply. Here’s What to Know.
description: Health officials have revised their recommendations on which children should receive the new drug.
content: Pediatricians and parents are having difficulty accessing a new immunization used to prevent severe respiratory syncytial virus infections in infants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard and Safak Timur
title: Turkey’s Leader, Lashing Out at Israel, Defends Hamas
description: In a speech in Parliament, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey accused Israel of committing “massacres” in Gaza and said Hamas was fighting for “liberation.”
content: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey lashed out at Israel and defended Hamas during a televised address on Wednesday, taking positions likely to increase tensions between his government and those of other NATO members, including the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: A Relative of Israeli Hostages Has a Message for the U.N.
description: The latest from the Israel-Hamas war. Weekday afternoons with Lulu Garcia-Navarro, and Times journalists on the ground.
content: This week, a dramatic public battle has been playing out between the United Nations, Israel and the United States. On Wednesday, the U.N. Security Council voted down two competing resolutions on the Israel-Hamas war. These votes came one day after Israel called for the U.N. secretary general to resign in response to his comments that the Oct. 7 attack by Hamas on Israel, while appalling, “cannot justify the collective punishment of the Palestinian people.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Do You Have Questions About the Trump Trials?
description: Share them, and we’ll try to give answers.
content: Donald Trump is facing an array of legal threats in the months ahead, with cases that span multiple jurisdictions and include dozens of charges. Sorting through the investigations and understanding what they mean for Trump, and for the country, can be baffling. But we’re here to help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aric Toler, Haley Willis, Riley Mellen, Alexander Cardia, Natalie Reneau, Julian E. Barnes and Christoph Koettl
title: A Close Look at Some Key Evidence in the Gaza Hospital Blast
description: A widely cited missile video does not shed light on what happened, a Times analysis concludes.
content: The video shows a projectile streaking through the darkened skies over Gaza and exploding in the air. Seconds later, another explosion is seen on the ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: House Declares Solidarity With Israel in First Legislation Under New Speaker
description: The resolution pledges to support Israel with whatever it needs as it fights Hamas. It passed overwhelmingly, but a small group of mostly Democratic holdouts remained.
content: The House voted overwhelmingly on Wednesday to pass a resolution declaring solidarity with Israel, pledging to give its government whatever security assistance it needs to fight and win its war with Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Goldbaum, Alex Kingsbury and Alexander Stockton
title: Pick a Side. Pick a Side. Pick a Side. Now.
description: Social media demands that you’re with us or against us.
content: There is precious little space on social media for nuance or neutrality when it comes to the war between Israel and Hamas. No matter what you think of the conflict, expressions of solidarity aren’t just appreciated; they are expected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Nashville Chief’s Son, Wanted in Shooting of Two Officers, Is Found Dead
description: John Drake Jr. was accused of shooting two police officers outside a Dollar General store on Saturday. Officials said he was found dead on Tuesday night.
content: The Nashville police chief’s estranged son, who was recently identified as a suspect in the shooting of two police officers outside a Dollar General store in La Vergne, Tenn., was found dead on Tuesday night, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich and Kate Christobek
title: Trump Told to Pay $10,000 in New Punishment for Breaking Gag Order
description: Outside Donald J. Trump’s civil fraud trial, the former president made comments to reporters that the judge found were an attack on a court employee.
content: A Manhattan judge on Wednesday ordered Donald J. Trump to the witness stand, questioned him personally, found that his answers were not believable and fined him $10,000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Even in Their Anguish, These Israeli Survivors Say Invading Gaza Won’t Help
description: “I don’t stop crying. I’m crying for my parents … I’m crying for the victims on the Palestinian side.”
content: No one understands terrorism more viscerally than Maoz Inon: His 78-year-old father and 75-year-old mother were among those massacred by Hamas this month in southern Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: The House Finally Elects a Speaker
description: Also, a surprisingly powerful hurricane hit Mexico. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: After three weeks of legislative paralysis and intraparty fighting, the narrow House Republican majority finally united this afternoon around a new leader. Representative Mike Johnson of Louisiana, with all 220 Republicans in favor and all 209 Democrats in opposition, was elected as the 56th speaker of the House of Representatives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kimmelman
title: When the Skyscraper You Hate Blocks the Skyscraper You Love
description: Views of the Empire State Building are being obscured by a new 860-foot luxury tower rising just blocks away. Should New York regulate its skyline?
content: Sometimes New York’s a downer. I had an appointment the other day near Madison Square Park.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle and Michael Gonchar
title: 25 Short Films for Exploring the Joys and Challenges of Growing Up
description: A collection of mini-documentaries about young people’s coming-of-age.
content: How do we help students reflect on the complexities of growing up — the self doubt, unbounded curiosity, growing independence, deep frustration and genuine hope and fear that children and teenagers experience as they form their identities and interact with today’s complicated world?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seph Rodney
title: A Giant of Painting Sheds New Light on Darkness
description: In his explorations of black, Pierre Soulages found a link to our sorrows, despair, regrets — our deepest selves.
content: “Some darknesses refuse to fade,” the poet Danielle DeTiberus observed after contemplating “Judith Beheading Holofernes” by Artemisia Gentileschi. Having recently seen the dark paintings by Pierre Soulages at Lévy Gorvy Dayan gallery, in Manhattan, the poet’s lyric resonated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ligaya Mishan
title: A Luxurious Squash and Lamb Stew for the Holidays
description: This earthy-sweet Nigerian dish is worthy of occasion.
content: When the Nigerian writer Yemisi Aribisala craves jollof rice, a West African staple, she doesn’t cook it. She asks her sister to send her a bowl. They live about an hour apart, so it is not a casual delivery. Nevertheless, this is how things must be. “Mine is simply not good enough,” Aribisala says.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: If You Plant Milkweed, They Will Come. (And Not Just the Butterflies.)
description: These underappreciated plants attract a “hungry throng” of beneficial insects. They’re not bad to look at, either.
content: To see a field of common milkweed in midsummer — a sea of a thousand nodding pink flower heads — you would not imagine that anything could ever stand in the way of the genus Asclepias.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Israel’s Strikes on Gaza Are Some of the Most Intense This Century
description: In the 19 days since Hamas attacked Israel, the Israeli military says it has struck more than 7,000 targets in Gaza. Palestinians accuse Israel of indiscriminately targeting civilians, but Israel officials say the strikes are aimed at eroding military infrastructure.
content: Israel’s 19-day bombing campaign in Gaza has become one of the most intense of the 21st century, prompting growing global scrutiny of its scale, purpose and cost to human life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: ‘We Still Don’t Have Answers’: A Uvalde Mother Is Running for Mayor
description: After her daughter was killed in a mass shooting in Uvalde, Kimberly Mata-Rubio figured it was time to get answers and help her city heal.
content: On a recent Saturday morning, a day after what would have been Lexi Rubio’s 12th birthday, dozens gathered in the Texas city of Uvalde for a run in her honor. Blasting Lexi’s playlist, Kimberly Mata-Rubio, her mother, took off from under a towering mural of Lexi, one of 19 children and two teachers killed in a shooting at her school last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dina Gachman
title: Margaret Renkl Writes in the Space Between Grief and Hope
description: In her most recent book, “The Comfort of Crows,” Renkl puts her admirable powers of perception to use, offering readers respite, and reason for hope, in a turbulent world.
content: The yard grows wild with pollinator blooms. It’s early October in Nashville and the scorching summer just relinquished its relentless hold. Many of the black-eyed Susans, sunflowers, and zinnias have been picked dry by birds and insects. The caretaker of this garden, the author and essayist Margaret Renkl, leads me to her leaf-strewn deck out back, to show me a glimmer of hope.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Stop Micromanaging Halloween — Let Your Kids Be Free
description: Endless scripting and too much control are helping destroy children’s sense of independence.
content: I started hearing about the Switch Witch a few years ago. If you’re not in the know, she’s the Halloween cousin of that narc, Elf on the Shelf, a symbol of the rank combination of child surveillance and endless materialism that dictates so much of mainstream American parenting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Ben Casselman
title: Biden Seeks to Tame Oil Prices if Mideast Conflict Sends Them Soaring
description: The president has previously drawn down the Strategic Petroleum Reserve to ease price pressures, but that could be more difficult now
content: Biden administration officials, worried that a growing conflict in the Middle East could send global oil prices soaring, are looking for ways to hold down American gasoline prices if such a jump occurs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley
title: Congestion Pricing Delays Threaten Subway Projects, M.T.A. Chair Says
description: A plan to toll drivers in Manhattan is expected to fund major improvements to New York City’s transit network. Officials fear delays threaten those plans.
content: New Jersey’s attempt to block new tolls to enter Manhattan risks the funding to improve the subway and bus network, New York transit officials said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: A Reclusive Horror Designer Pivoted From Religious Games
description: Before creating Five Nights at Freddy’s, whose jump scares will soon target moviegoers, Scott Cawthon was making indie video games like Noah’s Ark and The Pilgrim’s Progress.
content: Many times, in many ways, for many reasons, the “Five Nights at Freddy’s” movie almost never happened. It always came down to Scott Cawthon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Wednesday Briefing
description: The U.N. calls for a cease-fire in Israel and Gaza.
content: The United Nations secretary general, António Guterres, called yesterday for a humanitarian cease-fire in Israel and Gaza in an address to the U.N. Security Council. He said that the attacks by Hamas that had left 1,400 people dead in Israel on Oct. 7 were “appalling” but that they did not justify the “collective punishment” of civilians in the Gaza Strip, where the Israeli military significantly stepped up its bombardment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mireille Silcoff
title: Why ‘The Golden Bachelor’ Terrifies Me
description: Television celebrates older people — but only for seeming like sexy young ones.
content: In the first episode of ABC’s “The Golden Bachelor” — the new 60-plus addition to the decades-old “Bachelor” franchise — Gerry Turner, 72, puts in his hearing aids, dons a tuxedo and cries within the first three minutes of airtime. Gerry, our Golden Bachelor, has been widowed for six years. His wife, Toni, died suddenly, of an infection, and in describing her passing he cannot contain his grief. We see photos of their lives together, from young marrieds to parents, from middle-aged partners to retirees enjoying themselves on a boat. Gerry is uncommonly slim and good-looking and seems to have been so throughout these various life stages. Toni, whose age is not specified, ages less magically. Her waist and eyeglasses thicken, as these things tend to. Clearly these changes did not dampen Gerry’s adoration. The type of tears he sheds on camera over her passing reveal what looks like a deep and enduring love — the thing every contestant on the set of “The Golden Bachelor” is now competing to find with him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Scott
title: If You Can Take the Cable Car to the Colosseum, You’re in Vietnam
description: The country is in the middle of a cable-car bonanza, much of it driven by the over-the-top developments of the Sun Group, which feature giant Buddhas, ersatz European enclaves and selfie spots galore.
content: We are inside a glass box of a gondola, part of the longest passenger cable car in the world, flying silently along on a nearly five-mile ride, and some 50 stories above a sapphire sea just off the coast of Phu Quoc Island in southern Vietnam. On this bright March afternoon, hundreds of colorful wooden fishing boats speckle the crystalline water below as we sail toward Hon Thom Island.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Is California’s Fire Season Over?
description: So far, 2023 has been a relatively mild fire year for the state, but the final few months on the calendar have often proved to be dangerous ones.
content: Anyone looking at data from California’s fire season this year may be tempted to breathe a sigh of relief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: In Johnson, House Republicans Elevate One of Their Staunchest Conservatives
description: The new speaker played a pivotal role in congressional efforts to overturn the 2020 election and opposes abortion rights and gay marriage.
content: When Representative Mike Johnson of Louisiana wanted to make the case against abortion rights last year during a Capitol Hill committee hearing, he grilled a witness in graphic fashion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: House Elects Mike Johnson as Speaker, Embracing a Hard-Right Conservative
description: Republicans turned to a little-known Louisiana lawmaker who led congressional efforts to overturn the 2020 election, ending a weekslong deadlock that paralyzed the House.
content: Representative Mike Johnson of Louisiana won election on Wednesday to become the 56th speaker of the House of Representatives, as Republicans worn down by three weeks of infighting and dysfunction turned to a little-known conservative hard-liner beloved by the far right to end their paralysis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: mélange
description: This word has appeared in 48 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word mélange has appeared in 48 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on March 21 in “Matthew Macfadyen Has Mixed Feelings About the End of ‘Succession’” by Sarah Lyall:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: Public Schools Struggle to Say the Right Thing About the Israel-Hamas War
description: Across the country, public schools, like colleges and universities, are facing backlash as they try to respond to the Hamas attacks and war in Gaza.
content: In Atlanta, Jewish parents criticized the school district’s statement on “the violence facing children and families in the Middle East” for never using the word “terrorism.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein
title: Publisher Scholastic Backtracks on Isolating Works on Race and Gender
description: The company was faulted for the practice, which it said was an effort to help schools navigate new laws restricting books about racism and L.G.B.T.Q. identities.
content: The children’s book publisher Scholastic, which had begun separating some books about race, gender and sexuality at school book fairs, said this week it was halting the new practice after pointed criticism from some authors, educators and parents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: How Will Israel Pay for Its War?
description: The conflict has raised questions about how much state aid the ultra-Orthodox and settlers receive.
content: While the world’s eyes are on Gaza, another drama is unfolding in Jerusalem. There, lawmakers and government ministers are tussling over how to pay for the war against Hamas. There’s a debate over how much, if any, of the money should come from special allotments that were made earlier this year to the ultra-Orthodox and to settlers in the West Bank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Tanis
title: This Showstopping Three-Course Dinner Is as Easy and Light as It Gets
description: Impress your friends without much effort with this menu from David Tanis: a spiced carrot soup, a roasted fish with lemon and a lovely orange-pomegranate finish.
content: A few things to consider when planning a November dinner party: It’s important to celebrate the newly arrived fall produce and the change in weather. It’s time for all manner of warming, homey fare. But also: The month signals the start of “the holiday season” and all its various temptations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Brian Seibert
title: Review: Slow Poses and Clouds of White Powder
description: Sankai Juku, an all-male Butoh company, returns to New York with a program of greatest hits that too often feels tedious.
content: Men with shaved heads, their bodies caked in white powder, move with exacting slowness. Their motions and poses are often inscrutable, but their faces are sometimes telegraphic, contorting into open-mouthed expressions of amusement or agony as readable as the masks of comedy and tragedy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Hundreds of Shadow Puppets Were Stolen. A Bystander Helped Crack the Case.
description: Many of the puppets were still missing, however, after the theft of a U-haul truck in San Francisco holding props for the critically acclaimed Persian epic “Song of the North.” It was unclear if the show would go on.
content: Inside the U-Haul were nearly 500 handmade shadow puppets and dozens of masks, costumes and backdrops — the culmination of three years of painstaking labor, which, on Sunday evening, came to life in a balletic performance before a crowd of hundreds at a theater in San Francisco.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kayla Guo
title: Jamaal Bowman Charged With Setting Off False Fire Alarm
description: The congressman from New York set off the alarm in the Cannon House Office Building last month as Democrats were stalling for time to read a spending bill.
content: Prosecutors in the District of Columbia on Wednesday charged Representative Jamaal Bowman, Democrat of New York, with setting off a false fire alarm in a House office building last month in an episode that added to a day of mayhem on Capitol Hill as Congress rushed to avoid a government shutdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Carnival Was Negligent in Covid Outbreak on Cruise Ship, Court Rules
description: An Australian judge found that the cruise company and a subsidiary “breached their duty of care” in handling a coronavirus outbreak on the Ruby Princess in March 2020.
content: The coronavirus was already devastating parts of the world, bringing illness and death, and the future was uncertain when Henry Karpik, a retired police officer from the Australian suburb of Figtree, and his wife of nearly 50 years, Susan Karpik, began their holiday cruise to New Zealand aboard the Ruby Princess.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Visit the Library From the Comfort of Your Own Phone
description: With a free library card and the right app, you can check out e-books, audiobooks and more from your local branch.
content: Public libraries have lent e-books to patrons for more than 20 years, but many have widened their electronic offerings with digital audiobooks, magazines, comics, videos and other services, even before the pandemic helped shift collections online. If you are curious about what your local library can lend from its digital shelves but never got around to signing up for a free library card — or connecting your existing card to an account — here’s how to get started.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: Trump’s Lawyers Are Going Down. Is He?
description: It’s hard to know what to make of the guilty pleas in Georgia.
content: On Tuesday morning, Jenna Ellis became the third Donald Trump-allied lawyer to plead guilty in Fulton County, Ga., to state criminal charges related to his efforts to overturn the results of the 2020 presidential election in Georgia. She joins Sidney Powell and Kenneth Chesebro in similar pleas, with each of them receiving probation and paying a small fine and each of them cooperating with the prosecution in its remaining cases against Trump and his numerous co-defendants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Suhasini Raj and Atul Loke
title: A Hindu Goddess Festival Where Indian Progressivism Is Alive and Well
description: A huge religious carnival shows that India remains a country of diverse political and social beliefs, despite the right-wing national government’s dominance.
content: Purbasha Roy held her 9-year-old daughter’s hand and pointed toward the towering art installation: blooming pink buds symbolizing embryos, menstrual cups shaped to form a bouquet, fallopian tubes descending from corners of the ceiling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wilson
title: Among New York’s Sidewalk Sideshows, 2 Goats and a Story of Despair
description: In a city thick with spectacles and showmen, Beverly Shaw arrived from Indiana with a desperate plea.
content: The short, slender woman clutches two leashes in her right hand. At their ends are two goats, Marshmallow and Brownie. The three of them stand in the human jet stream of Rockefeller Center, and people stop to take pictures or pet the animals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hikari Hida and Motoko Rich
title: Transgender Ruling Is Step Forward for L.G.B.T.Q. Rights in Japan
description: The Supreme Court declared unconstitutional a legal clause requiring transgender people to undergo sterilization to legally change their gender identity.
content: Japan’s Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday that requiring transgender people to undergo sterilization in order to legally change their gender identity is unconstitutional, a step forward for L.G.B.T.Q. rights in a nation that has been slow to recognize them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Knight
title: California Slams San Francisco for ‘Egregious’ Barriers to Housing Construction
description: The city adopted a state-approved plan in January to build 82,000 new housing units in eight years. It’s already failing.
content: A scathing new report has found that it takes longer and costs more to build housing in San Francisco than anywhere else in California, exacerbating the state’s homelessness crisis and preventing many workers from being able to live in the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette and Noam Scheiber
title: U.A.W. and Ford Reach Tentative Contract Agreement
description: The deal, subject to approval by union members, could ease the way for deals with General Motors and Stellantis and end a growing wave of walkouts.
content: The United Automobile Workers and Ford Motor have reached a tentative agreement on a new four-year labor contract, the union announced Wednesday, nearly six weeks after the union began a growing wave of walkouts against the three Detroit automakers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Taylor Swift’s ‘1989’ May Be Her Biggest Rerecording Yet. Here’s Why.
description: The pop superstar’s new version of her 2014 blockbuster is due Friday, following a summer of media saturation and her 10th No. 1 hit.
content: Taylor Swift’s “1989” has been a fixture in the Top 20 of Billboard’s album chart for months. Stuffed with some of the singer’s biggest pop hits, like “Shake It Off” and “Blank Space,” the LP was a gargantuan hit when it was released in 2014, and this year Swift has been performing its songs on her record-breaking Eras Tour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Farago
title: Mark Rothko at Full Scale, and in Half Light
description: Sublime and vulgar all at once, his diaphanous stains of color have come together in a once-in-a-generation show in Paris.
content: Melt the world away, lose its details, dissolve its borders; it doesn’t sound like such an unwelcome prospect right now. The most substantial Mark Rothko retrospective in a generation has opened at the Fondation Louis Vuitton, and it is a show of monumental dispersion: a pull-out-all-the-stops blockbuster where life passes into vapor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: What I Read and Watch to Decompress
description: Some Jane Austen and a tennis rom-com are just right the right relief when news of fighting and war takes a toll.
content: It has been an intense couple of weeks here at Interpreter HQ. “India’s Daughters,” the special newsletter series that I created with my colleagues Emily Schmall and Shalini Venugopal Bhagat, premiered last week. There will be a new chapter on Friday, and you can catch up with the first installment here if you missed it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mahira Rivers
title: In Brooklyn, a Honduran-Inspired Backyard Dinner
description: Cathleen O’Neil and Feisal Lagos, two friends who met in the New York events industry, have started a vibrant, collaborative meal series of their own.
content: On a warm evening, not long before her guests were set to arrive, Cathleen O’Neil, 30, was stocking the bar for a dinner party at her home in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, while her co-host, the chef Feisal Lagos, 39, was hastily adding the finishing touches to his handwritten menu. “The point,” he said, “is for people not to notice that you’re paying attention to those details.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Stella Tan, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Mooj Zadie, Michael Benoist, Liz O. Baylen, Diane Wong, Pat McCusker and Chris Wood
title: Why Israel Is Delaying the Ground Invasion
description: More than two weeks after the attack by Hamas, Israeli troops are still massing near the Gaza border.
content: Almost immediately after Israel was attacked on Oct. 7, it began preparing for a ground invasion of Gaza, drafting hundreds of thousands of its citizens and amassing forces along its southern border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones
title: Why Hurricane Otis Caught Many By Surprise
description: Storms don’t normally go from a tropical storm to a Category 5 hurricane in a day.
content: On Tuesday morning, few meteorologists were talking about Tropical Storm Otis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anita Gates
title: Richard Roundtree, Star of ‘Shaft,’ Dies at 81
description: While indelibly tied to the role that made him famous in 1971, he remained active for more than four decades afterward.
content: Richard Roundtree, the actor who redefined African American masculinity in the movies when he played the title role in “Shaft,” one of the first Black action heroes, died on Tuesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Floating Home
description: Would you want to live in a house on the water?
content: As sea levels rise and storms worsen, threatening the planet’s coastlines, some architects and developers are looking to “push cities into the water” by creating floating homes and other structures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: Five TV Treats for Halloween
description: “Creepshow,” “The Fall of the House of Usher” and other shows serve up humor with their horror.
content: Sorting through the seasonal bounty of horror and supernatural television series timed to Halloween, I have focused on shows that approach the grim task with a sense of humor. Here, in alphabetical order, are five series released this month that put more emphasis on wit than on sheer terror.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: Is Social Media Addictive? Here’s What the Science Says.
description: A major lawsuit against Meta has placed a spotlight on our fraught relationship with online social information.
content: A group of 41 states and the District of Columbia filed suit on Tuesday against Meta, the parent company of Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp and Messenger, contending that the company knowingly used features on its platforms to cause children to use them compulsively, even as the company said that its social media sites were safe for young people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jo Becker
title: Justice Thomas’s R.V. Loan Was Forgiven, Senate Inquiry Finds
description: The justice failed to repay much, perhaps all, of the $267,230 loan. His benefactor wiped the slate clean, with ethical and potential tax consequences.
content: The terms of the private loan were as generous as they were clear: With no money down, Justice Clarence Thomas could borrow more than a quarter of a million dollars from a wealthy friend to buy a 40-foot luxury motor coach, making annual interest-only payments for five years. Only then would the principal come due.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Allows Mobile Sports Bets at Florida Indian Casinos
description: Brick-and-mortar gambling venues in the state objected to a deal that deemed remote wagers handled by Indian casinos to have been made “on tribal lands.”
content: The Supreme Court allowed a Native American tribe in Florida on Wednesday to offer online sports betting on mobile devices throughout the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: A Once Powerful Fashion Executive Testifies in His Sexual Assault Trial
description: A lawyer for Peter Nygard, a former fashion executive accused of sexually assaulting five women, described their testimony as “revisionist history.’’
content: Peter Nygard, the former fashion executive behind a now defunct Canadian clothing brand, took the stand at a Toronto courthouse on Wednesday to counter what his lawyer called the “revisionist history” put forth by five women who have accused him of sexual assault.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Iwuk Edesi, Bright and Savory and Satisfying
description: A gorgeous one-pot chicken and rice from Yewande Komolafe’s new cookbook.
content: Since the minute my colleague Yewande Komolafe told me she was working on a cookbook about Nigerian cuisine, I’ve been longing for the day I could read and cook from it, cover to cover. The wait is finally over! “My Everyday Lagos,” an exploration of the richness and diversity of Nigerian food, is out in the world — and it’s out of this world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: A New Subway Attack, and New Pressure for Protective Gates
description: A shoving in the subway renewed old fears, even though crime is down underground.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll look at why a violent attack last week renewed attention on ways to make subway platforms safer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Jill Medvedow, Who Remade ICA Boston, to Depart
description: She will leave her post as the Institute of Contemporary Art’s director in 2024, but isn’t sure what’s next. “I don’t think I am capable of real retirement,” Medvedow said.
content: After nearly 25 years as the director for the Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston, Jill Medvedow has decided to move on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katy Balls
title: Rishi Sunak Is Trying His Best. He’s Probably Still Doomed.
description: A sense of fatalism surrounds Britain’s prime minister.
content: When Rishi Sunak became prime minister of Britain a year ago, there was little sense of celebration. The markets were in free fall after the disastrous 49-day tenure of his predecessor, Liz Truss, and the government was in disarray. Mr. Sunak, who had been rejected by Conservative Party members earlier in the year, was inserted by lawmakers in the desperate hope he could calm the crisis. Given that the party had just ousted two leaders in quick succession, it was unclear how long he would even stay in the post.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Newly Published Poetry, From Katy Lederer to The Shining
description: A selection of recently published books.
content: HOW FIRE DESCENDS: New and Selected Poems, by Serhiy Zhadan. Translated by Virlana Tkacz and Wanda Phipps. (Yale University Press, paperback, $18.) In these poems, compiled from 2016 to 2022, the Ukrainian poet commemorates the plight of his compatriots in the face of Russian imperialism and mourns their deaths, “limited / by the silence that comes with it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlos Aguilar
title: ‘The Nightmare Before Christmas’: A Hit That Initially Unnerved Disney
description: The filmmakers look back on its 30th anniversary and recall how uncomfortable it made executives. They didn’t expect the celebrations around it today.
content: “What’s this?” Jack Skellington sings excitedly when he first comes across Santa Claus’s snowy, colorful village in “The Nightmare Before Christmas.” That’s also what Disney executives asked with concern about the idiosyncratic stop-motion animation musical when they saw a rough cut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Poison Specialist Accused in Wife’s Death, Authorities Say
description: Dr. Connor Bowman was charged with murder after investigators found that his wife, Betty Bowman, was poisoned with a drug that he had researched online.
content: A Minnesota doctor who the authorities said had worked as a poison specialist was arrested on Friday and charged in the death of his wife, Betty Bowman, who died in August from poisoning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Wu
title: The Father-Son Struggle That Helped Ensure IBM’s Success
description: In “The Greatest Capitalist Who Ever Lived,” Ralph Watson McElvenny and Marc Wortman show how Oedipal battles fueled the company’s technological triumphs in the 1960s and beyond.
content: Thomas J. Watson Jr. seemed, from a young age, to be destined for failure. Born in 1914, he was an angry and often depressed young boy. Neighbors called him “Terrible Tommy.” He barely gained his high school diploma after attending three different schools. His father, Watson Sr., the head of IBM, was a domineering man who subjected his son to a classic combination of emotional distance and cruelty. Watson Jr. responded by becoming a rebel and wastrel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Darren Incorvaia
title: Mirror, Mirror on the Wall, Cock-a-Doodle-Doo
description: A modified version of the classic mirror test suggested that roosters recognize their reflections.
content: The idea of a chicken running around with its head cut off, inspired by a real-life story, may make it seem like the bird doesn’t have much going on upstairs. But Sonja Hillemacher, an animal behavior researcher at the University of Bonn in Germany, always knew that chickens were more than mindless sources of wings and nuggets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: Chasing Big Mergers, Oil Executives Dismiss Peak Oil Concerns
description: Exxon Mobil and Chevron are spending tens of billions of dollars buying oil and gas assets, betting that the International Energy Agency’s predictions of declining oil demand are wrong.
content: Exxon Mobil and Chevron, the two largest U.S. oil companies, this month committed to spending more than $50 billion each to buy smaller companies in deals that would let them produce more oil and natural gas for decades to come.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Teaching Practical Skills Like Home Ec and Shop in School
description: Readers agree with Pamela Paul about bringing back those classes. Also: Donald Trump’s provocations; mental health and TikTok; Israel and Ukraine.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Long on Hype, A.I. Is No Guarantee for Profits
description: The latest quarterly results from Microsoft and Alphabet show that their big investments in artificial intelligence are on different trajectories.
content: The Nasdaq composite index looks set to open in the red on Wednesday, after investors got a split-screen view of how two tech giants, Microsoft and Alphabet, were doing in efforts to profit from artificial intelligence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: The Best True Crime to Stream: Stories That Are Very Scary, and Real
description: Four terrifying, unnerving picks across television, film and podcast.
content: It’s the time of year when I tend to push the boundaries of how many scary stories I can stomach. That includes horror movies, but also, true crime offerings that I may have skipped. Of course, with true crime, that self-soothing mantra of “at least it’s not real” doesn’t apply, which makes it all the more haunting. Here are four picks that shook me to my core.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: New York City Has a Bold Plan to Fix Its Housing Crisis. Will It Work?
description: A new plan unveiled this month aims to make way for new housing and ease the pressures that drive up rents and home prices. Whether it will work is less clear.
content: Last month, Mayor Eric Adams unveiled a big plan to tackle New York City’s housing shortage and make the city more affordable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Biden Reaffirms Support for Israel but Calls for Protection of Civilians
description: During an appearance with the Australian prime minister, President Biden pledged that the United States would provide Israel with what it needed to defend itself against Hamas.
content: President Biden expressed forceful support for Israel on Wednesday and cautioned that the country should do everything in its power to protect civilians but added that their deaths were ultimately “the price of waging a war.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: How Philip Roth’s Raunchiest Novel Made It to the Stage
description: For their adaptation of “Sabbath’s Theater,” John Turturro and Ariel Levy sought to preserve “the nasty side of existence” evoked in the book.
content: For John Turturro, it was time to honor Philip Roth. Turturro, the veteran actor, had been friends with the novelist for nearly a quarter-century when Roth died in 2018 at 85. They first met, Turturro recalled, after Roth saw his performance in the 1994 film “Quiz Show” and picked him to star in a one-man stage adaptation of “Portnoy’s Complaint,” Roth’s 1969 best seller about a young man with a penchant for self-pleasure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: G.O.P. Candidates Call for Campus Crackdowns Against Anti-Israel Speech
description: The G.O.P. field, including former President Trump, has been wading into the emotional debate among students playing out over the deadly war between Hamas and Israel.
content: As tensions mount on U.S. college campuses over the war in Gaza, several Republican presidential candidates are proposing a crackdown on students and schools that express opposition to Israel, appear to express support for the deadly Hamas attacks or fail to address antisemitism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Next Speaker Vote Is Expected in Hours in a Leaderless House
description: Representative Mike Johnson of Louisiana is the fourth Republican nominee for speaker, but it’s unclear if he can win the chair after the three before him failed because of G.O.P. infighting.
content: It was clear from the start that House Republicans would struggle to govern this year given their deep ideological divisions, narrow majority and myriad personal feuds and grudges. But even the most pessimistic of predictions could not have captured the remarkable, drawn-out Republican self-own now raging on Capitol Hill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Solidarity Between American Activists and Palestinians — Including a Rebuke of Biden
description: An increasingly disaffected activist base on the left could be disastrous for the president in 2024.
content: Since the heinous Oct. 7 Hamas attacks and Israel’s declaration of war against the terrorist group, I have been going over and over a question I’ve not been able to answer fully: During this episode, why has the Palestinian cause sparked so much passion among veteran activists of the movement for Black lives?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Terry Dischinger, College Basketball Star and Olympian, Dies at 82
description: An all-American at Purdue, he was the youngest member of the gold medal-winning 1960 U.S. Olympic team. He later became a top N.B.A. rookie.
content: Terry Dischinger, one of the greatest players in Purdue University basketball history and the youngest member of the U.S. Olympic team that won a gold medal in Rome in 1960, died on Oct. 9 in Lake Oswego, Ore. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Jimmy Kimmel: ‘Altoids Last Longer Than These Republican Nominees’
description: “This morning, I didn’t even know who Tom Emmer was,” Kimmel said about a short-lived candidate for House speaker. “Now, I still don’t. I have no idea.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May and Shawn Hubler
title: Gavin Newsom, on Climate Mission to China, Gets an Audience With Xi
description: The California governor is on a weeklong visit to China aimed at negotiating climate partnerships.
content: Gavin Newsom, the governor of California, met with China’s leader, Xi Jinping, in Beijing on Wednesday, as part of an ambitious weeklong mission to negotiate climate partnerships.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: As Bombs Fall in Gaza, History Hangs Over a Family Fighting to Survive
description: From his Los Angeles home, Mohammed Abujayyab has sought to help his grandmother and other relatives survive the Israeli bombardment. Memories of displacement are never far.
content: Mohammed Abujayyab was at his wits’ end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: Let’s Talk About Holiday Family Drama
description: How do you cope with tricky relationships and thorny topics? We want to hear your stories.
content: The holiday season is around the corner, and there are so many beloved rituals and traditions to look forward to.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: Review: In ‘Daphne,’ Remaking a Myth, With Mixed Results
description: The playwright Renae Simone Jarrett makes her professional stage debut with a surreal reworking of a Greek myth about a river nymph.
content: A crying baby pulled from a kitchen cabinet, a woman abruptly exiting a house via a window and a banged-up finger that turns into bark: The new play “Daphne” is chock-full of magical surprises and mystical transformations, but its surreal elements leave the audience with too many unanswered questions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Will Playing the Lottery in Southern California Turn You Into a Billionaire?
description: Maybe!
content: Southern California has been on a fairly extraordinary winning streak. The streak itself is small, but the numbers involved are big: billions-of-dollars big.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: What Guilty Pleas in Georgia Mean for the Federal Case Against Trump
description: The guilty pleas present a host of challenges as state and federal prosecutors engage in parallel efforts to hold Donald J. Trump accountable, defense lawyers and former federal prosecutors say.
content: Jack Smith, the special counsel investigating former President Donald J. Trump, brought a streamlined case against Mr. Trump in accusing him of trying to subvert democracy — with the goal of moving the case rapidly to trial in a presidential election year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Who Invited Ivanka?
description: Kim Kardashian hosted the shunned socialite to her birthday party, then posted the photos for her 364 million followers.
content: Over the weekend, something happened to Ivanka Trump that hasn’t occurred since before her father was elected president: Celebrities were willing to be seen with her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: It’s a Must
description: Aimee Lucido ensnares our attention.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hala Alyan
title: The Palestine Double Standard
description: The task of the Palestinian is to audition for empathy and compassion. To prove that we deserve it.
content: I’ve moved back to the United States twice since my birth. Once as a child, after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Then again for graduate school. I’d had the privilege of a youth — adolescence and young adulthood — in countries where being Palestinian was fairly common. The identity could be heavy, but it wasn’t a contested one. I hadn’t had to learn the respectability politics of being a Palestinian adult. I learned quickly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Judson Jones and Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: A ‘Nightmare Scenario’ Hurricane Batters Mexico’s Western Coast
description: Hurricane Otis defied forecasts when it quickly transformed from a tropical storm into a Category 5 storm and slammed into the coastal city of Acapulco.
content: Hurricane Otis exploded onto the southwest coast of Mexico early Wednesday, shocking forecasters as it emerged as one of the more powerful Category 5 storms to batter the region and create what one expert called a “nightmare scenario” for a popular tourist coastline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe, Cecilia Kang and Steve Lohr
title: What the U.S. Has Argued in the Google Antitrust Trial
description: As the government wraps up its case in the landmark monopoly trial, it has built a picture of how Google became dominant in online search — and the harms that it says resulted.
content: Since Sept. 12., the Department of Justice and a group of state attorneys general have questioned more than 30 witnesses as they try to prove that Google broke antitrust laws, in a landmark monopoly trial that may affect the power of the technology industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: In Israel and Gaza, Photos Show the Human Cost of War
description: Four photojournalists, two in Israel and two in Gaza, provided context behind their powerful images.
content: Bodies in black bags, lined up on the ground in the Israeli village of Kfar Azza. A woman holding the body of her grandson in Khan Younis, Gaza. Devastated mourners at a funeral for their loved ones. A man, wounded and dazed, following an airstrike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terence McGinley
title: Your Guide Through America’s Dining Scene
description: The Times’s Food team has eaten its way through cities across the country so you don’t have to … but we highly recommend you do.
content: In 2021, when patrons were wary but excited to return to restaurants after long Covid-19 shutdowns, the Food section at The New York Times published its first national restaurant list. After months of visiting hallowed establishments and plucky upstarts across the country, reporters and editors chose the 50 restaurants in the United States they were “most excited about.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: The Full Guest List for Biden’s State Dinner With Australia
description: The Bidens invited more than 300 guests, including business leaders, musicians, athletes and prominent Australian Americans.
content: The White House invited more than 300 guests to the state dinner hosted by President Biden for Prime Minister Anthony Albanese of Australia on Wednesday night, including business leaders, musicians, athletes and prominent Australian Americans. Here is the full list of those invited as provided by the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blaze Lovell
title: Hawaii Bribery Scandal Casts a Shadow Over Lahaina’s Ruins
description: For years, a local businessman paid off officials in exchange for lucrative contracts. The system he exploited has been left largely unchanged.
content: After a major contracting scandal broke out in Hawaii last year, the mayor of Maui County appeared on television to express outrage and announce a sweeping audit of contracts awarded to a corrupt businessman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: How Can I Get Myself Invited to My Husband’s Family Parties?
description: A new wife is eager to join in the fun after her husband and brother-in-law wrap up their weekly jam sessions, but she’s reluctant to impose on her sister-in-law.
content: My new husband and his brother get together most weekends to play music with friends. They meet up in my brother-in-law’s large basement. These get-togethers turn into daylong events, culminating in dinners at local bars or drinks at my brother-in-law’s house. The problem: I’m often not invited! Since I don’t play music, I feel that my sister-in-law has to invite me to hang out with her while the boys jam. But her invitations are far less frequent than the gatherings. I appreciate that she has a busy life, but she usually ends up joining the others for drinks or dinner. And I feel left out: My husband, our friends and my in-laws are sharing meals every week while I sit at home alone because my sister-in-law doesn’t want to spend the day with me. Any advice for navigating this disappointing dynamic?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: 2 Jets Collide at Houston Airport After One Took Off Without Permission
description: No one was injured in the collision at Hobby Airport, which came as aviation officials have expressed concern over the regular near misses across the country.
content: Two jets collided at an airport in Houston on Tuesday when one took off without permission as another was landing, the National Transportation Safety Board said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: El Museo del Barrio Rejects Artwork Featuring Palestinian Flag
description: The museum had commissioned the work for its annual Día de los Muertos celebrations, but decided not to display it after the artists included a Palestinian flag in it.
content: El Museo del Barrio, a Manhattan museum dedicated to Puerto Rican and Latin American art, decided not to display an artwork it had commissioned for its annual Día de los Muertos celebrations this month after the artists included a Palestinian flag in it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: ‘Chaos Doesn’t Scare Me. American Decline Does.’
description: The Republican Party’s “lunge toward extremism” shows no sign of abating.
content: Jim Jordan’s bid last week to become speaker of the House — together with the withdrawal on Tuesday of Thomas Emmer from his campaign for the same job — revealed not only how far House Republicans have moved to the right but also how weak the intraparty forces for moderation have become.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: The Far Right Gets Its Man of the House
description: The new speaker, Mike Johnson, is virtually unknown to most Americans, but he can be expected to press a hard-right social and fiscal agenda.
content: In the end, Republican hard-liners got their man.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Shoplifting Surges in U.K., Putting Workers in Scary Situations
description: As people try to walk away with goods, it’s “like the Wild West,” says one store owner, whose employees have been hit and bitten on the job.
content: Stashing six bottles of wine into a bag, a man wearing a dark jacket and beanie heads straight to the store exit without paying, barging by a female shop worker who blocks his way and only stopping when her colleague overpowers him just outside the doorway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin George Andrews
title: A Radioactive Sea of Magma Hides Under the Surface of Mars
description: The discovery helped to show why the red planet’s core is not as large as earlier estimates had suggested it might be.
content: In 2021, it seemed as if Mars had a surprisingly big heart. Scientists had been using InSight, a robotic lander to study the planet’s insides. The spacecraft had listened to enough marsquakes to develop a picture of the layer-cake nature of the Martian underworld.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: It’s Covid Season. What Are the New Rules for Staying Safe?
description: A primer on how to minimize your risk and know when you’re in the clear after an exposure.
content: We want to be done with Covid. But the virus isn’t done with us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Lauren Halsey, an Activist Artist, Joins Gagosian Gallery
description: The artist, whose upbringing in South Central Los Angeles is integral to her practice, combines community and commercial success.
content: LOS ANGELES — Lauren Halsey, the Los Angeles artist who recently transformed the Metropolitan Museum’s rooftop into a contemporary monument and who created a food bank in her South Central neighborhood during Covid, is joining Gagosian, one of the largest art galleries, with 19 spaces worldwide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Tour de France Route Steers Clear of Olympics, and Paris
description: The 2024 Summer Games have pushed the iconic bike race out of its traditional finish in Paris. The Tour will instead end in Nice, in the south of France.
content: Everything makes way for the Olympics. Even an event as important to the host nation as the Tour de France.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yousur Al-Hlou
title: An Audio Diary of Despair
description: In a series of voice memos sent via WhatsApp, Tasneem Ismael Ahel, 19, described the war unfolding around her in Gaza City.
content: Tasneem Ismael Ahel’s audio messages typically arrive all at once.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: Wyna Liu, a Connections editor, answered reader questions about the game in the comments section of this article.
content: Editor’s note: Wyna Liu, a Connections editor, answered reader questions about the game in the comments section of this article. Read the conversation here.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Oct. 25, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Oct. 25, 2023.
content: An article on Tuesday about Gov. Gavin Newsom’s efforts to export California’s climate policies misstated the share of jobs linked to oil drilling in California. It is 0.2 percent, not 2 percent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany and Matthew Goldstein
title: Sam Bankman-Fried Set to Testify at His Fraud Trial
description: The FTX founder’s plan to take the witness stand sets up a dramatic few days of testimony at the federal courthouse in Manhattan.
content: Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of the failed cryptocurrency exchange FTX, is planning to testify at his criminal fraud trial in Manhattan, his lawyer said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: Rose Petals and Peacock Brains: What It Took to Be an ‘Emperor of Rome’
description: The classicist Mary Beard examines the excesses and tedium of imperial rule, sorting fact from gossip and tall tales.
content: If social media is to be believed, men can’t stop thinking about the Roman Empire, particularly its “alpha male” elements. Anyone similarly obsessed would do well to pick up a copy of “Emperor of Rome,” an erudite and entertaining new book by the redoubtable classics scholar and feminist Mary Beard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Rock Brynner, 76, Son of Hollywood Royalty Who Cut His Own Path, Dies
description: The only male child of the actor Yul Brynner, he built a peripatetic career as a writer, historian, novelist, playwright — and roadie for the Band.
content: Rock Brynner, whose life as a road manager for the Band, bodyguard for Muhammad Ali, farmer, pilot, street performer, novelist and professor of constitutional history overshadowed what, for a lesser mortal, might be a more than sufficient laurel on which to rest — he was the son of the actor Yul Brynner — died on Oct. 13 in Salisbury, Conn. He was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Lange
title: The Exhibition Making the Case for Art Without Men
description: Loved in her day, the French painter Marie Laurencin depicted a dreamy vision of a world of women. What does she have to say to audiences now?
content: “If you want what is commonly accepted as ‘a straight answer to a straight question,’ don’t go to Marie Laurencin to get it,” Dorothy Todd, the British magazine editor, wrote in 1928. If answers from Laurencin — one of the most notable female painters in interwar France — were anything like her work, of course they wouldn’t be straight, but coy, queer, covert and very pretty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gershom Gorenberg and Jillian Weinberger
title: Netanyahu Must Go
description: The responsibility Israel’s prime minister bears for Oct. 7.
content: Since Hamas’s horrific attacks, Israelis have been asking themselves how such an atrocity could have happened. In this audio essay, Gershom Gorenberg says the better question is: How did Israel’s leaders — specifically Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu — let it happen? The government was “complacent, overconfident, committed to misconceptions and has failed,” he says. Gorenberg believes it’s time for Netanyahu to step down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: The Trump Loyalty Test at the Center of Republicans’ Speaker Endgame
description: The developments on Capitol Hill highlighted the extent to which one of the greatest sins inside the Republican Party is to have certified Joseph R. Biden’s victory.
content: Representative Mike Johnson of Louisiana had just survived a closed-door vote to end a tumultuous period of paralysis without a House speaker on Tuesday night and was celebrating with smiling and exhausted Republican colleagues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Martin, Julia Botero, Christina Djossa, Hans Buetow, Cristal Duhaime, Jen Poyant, Anabel Bacon, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Pat McCusker, Rowan Niemisto, Sophia Lanman and Daniel Ramirez
title: I Wrote This Essay, but Then Changed My Mind
description: Heather Sellers thought she made peace with her estranged father years ago. But as she’s gotten older, she’s realized that complete forgiveness was never really on the table.
content: Heather Sellers wrote her Modern Love essay in 2013, about reconnecting with her elderly, estranged father. Although their relationship was painful, Heather made sure that her last words to her father were “I love you.” And at the time, that felt like closure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Berlinger
title: Gifts for Gardeners? They’ve Got Them in Spades.
description: With clothes inspired by Martha Stewart, heritage tools and colorful clogs, the couple behind Gardenheir cater to actual and want-to-be gardeners alike.
content: Alan Calpe and Christopher Crawford set out to make a shoe for gardeners. But the bulbous clogs they designed for their brand, Gardenheir, quickly found a wider audience after being introduced in 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Popcast (Deluxe): Britney Spears Tells … Some?
description: A conversation about the week in popular culture, including “The Woman in Me,” the new book by Spears, and “Killers of the Flower Moon,” Martin Scorsese’s latest film.
content: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, includes segments on:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: Meta Posts 23% Growth as Ads Rebound, With Profit More Than Doubling
description: The internet company’s cost cuts also helped lift its financial performance in the most recent quarter.
content: Mark Zuckerberg, Meta’s chief executive, spent the past two years weathering a slump in digital advertising and cutting costs. This year, he proclaimed, would be a “year of efficiency” for his company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $400,000 Homes in Oklahoma, South Carolina and Louisiana
description: A Craftsman house in Oklahoma City, a two-bedroom bungalow in North Charleston and a renovated 1850s cottage in New Orleans.
content: This house is on a tree-lined street near downtown, less than a 10-minute drive from the Oklahoma City Museum of Art and the bustling Oklahoma River waterfront. It is a few blocks from Lyric Theatre, a performing arts venue in a historic theater, and Plaza Walls, an outdoor arts space with murals by local artists. A public elementary school is less than a mile away, and a public high school is five minutes away by car.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein and William K. Rashbaum
title: Top Adviser to Mayor Adams Is Being Investigated Over Altercation
description: The Department of Investigation inquiry focuses on a violent exchange that the adviser, Timothy Pearson, had with security guards at a migrant shelter.
content: One of Mayor Eric Adams’s closest advisers is being formally investigated over a violent incident at a Manhattan migrant center, people with knowledge of the matter said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Darryn King
title: ‘Partnership’ Review: A Lost Tale of Ambition That Resonates
description: The Mint Theater revives Elizabeth Baker’s charming 1917 comedy, which offers a gentle reminder about work-life balance.
content: Find a job that you love and you’ll work every day of your life. So warns “Partnership,” the third Elizabeth Baker play to be staged by the Mint Theater Company, which has long nurtured the works of forgotten playwrights. Baker’s play premiered in 1917 in London, but the way it tackles the issue of work-life balance seems to speak more to the Great Resignation than to the Great War.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cat Zhang
title: Why Do Fan-Made Trailers Rule the Internet?
description: Fan edits — short montages of films and television shows like “Bottoms” and “Succession” set to music — have become a staple of online life.
content: By day, Emily McLaughlin pours pumpkin spice lattes as a Starbucks barista. By night, she roams the internet as a self-described “fictional gay-people enthusiast,” tirelessly posting about and promoting her favorite queer movies and television shows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: Chaos in the House
description: The Republican Party is in disarray.
content: In the past three weeks, House Republicans have dumped their party leader — Speaker Kevin McCarthy — and repeatedly failed to elect the candidate whom they had nominated to replace McCarthy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Salmonella Outbreak Linked to Packaged Onions Sickens 73
description: Gills Onions recalled packages of diced onions after the company was notified of an investigation. Public health officials said 15 people were treated at hospitals.
content: A salmonella outbreak linked to packages of diced onions has sickened at least 73 people across 22 states, 15 of whom were treated at hospitals, public health officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: Is It Ever OK to Use Strangers as Content for Social Media?
description: A Times writer says, in the age of TikTok, we need to reassess the rules of engagement. What do you think?
content: A person stops a stranger on the street to ask a question. Another performs an act of kindness. Another plays a prank. Another makes fun of someone without the person knowing. All of these interactions are recorded and then posted online, without the consent of the subject.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim and Samar Abu Elouf
title: Thirst and Hunger Grow in Besieged Gaza Amid Israeli Bombardment
description: Residents wait in line for hours for bread and water, with fights sometimes breaking out. The United Nations has called the situation a humanitarian catastrophe.
content: Mohammed Aborjela, 27, used to document daily life in the Gaza Strip on his Instagram account before the war, videos about a crab dish prepared along the seaside or pigeon racing in the coastal enclave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes and David E. Sanger
title: U.S. Cites ‘High Confidence’ That Palestinian Rocket Caused Hospital Blast
description: American intelligence agencies released no new declassified imagery or other new evidence to make their case. Officials said their strengthened assessment was based on video evidence.
content: American intelligence officials said Tuesday they now had “high confidence” that the blast at Al-Ahli Arab Hospital in Gaza last week was the result of a Palestinian rocket that broke up mid-flight, and that no Israeli weapon was involved in the explosion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Ofri
title: It Shouldn’t Be This Easy to Lose Your Health Insurance
description: Open enrollment reminds us how easy it is to lose coverage.
content: A few days before New Year’s Eve, an unfamiliar health insurance card for me arrived in the mail. I assumed there must have been an error and called the human resources department of the medical center where I’m employed as a doctor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: A traveler stranded in Acapulco recounts horrific conditions.
description: “It was really terrifying,” said one visitor who was attending a mining convention in the Mexican city.
content: Hurricane Otis interrupted tropical vacations for some visitors and put a stop to a mining convention in Acapulco, Mexico, as the storm bore down on the city early Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Danny Hakim
title: With Plea Deals in Georgia Trump Case, Fani Willis Is Building Momentum
description: The Fulton County district attorney often uses her state’s racketeering law to pressure lower-rung defendants to cooperate and exert pressure on her main targets.
content: Fani T. Willis, the district attorney of Fulton County, Ga., had no shortage of doubters when she brought an ambitious racketeering case in August against former president Donald J. Trump and 18 of his allies. It was too broad, they said, and too complicated, with so many defendants and multiple, crisscrossing plot lines for jurors to follow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jori Finkel
title: Robert Irwin, Artist of Fleeting Light and Space, Is Dead at 95
description: Part of a bold, experimental 1960s movement, his work, which could transform empty rooms with minimal gestures, challenged human perception.
content: Robert Irwin, a Southern California artist associated with the Light and Space movement of the 1960s, who early on stopped making paintings in favor of creating ephemeral and sometimes intangible art environments, died on Wednesday in the La Jolla section of San Diego. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Moises Velasquez-Manoff
title: Can We Save the Redwoods by Helping Them Move?
description: The largest trees on the planet can’t easily ‘migrate’ — but in a warming world, some humans are helping them try to find new homes.
content: When Philip Stielstra retired from Boeing in 2012, he needed something purposeful to do. He and his wife, Gay, were casual golfers, but Stielstra, an antiwar activist in college who refused to fight in Vietnam — he worked in a post office instead — wanted a pastime with bigger stakes. Before leaving his job, he received an email from the city of Seattle: The Parks and Recreation Department needed “tree ambassadors.” Tree canopy cover had receded in the city, and the department was responding by promoting an appreciation for its remaining trees. The volunteer ambassadors would learn about these trees and lead residents on walking tours to marvel at them. Stielstra, despite being a self-described introvert, signed up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk
title: With Fuel Scarce, U.N. Aid Group in Desperate Gaza May Scale Back
description: A U.N. agency that has offered a wartime lifeline to hundreds of thousands of Palestinians warned of “tough decisions” ahead if it cannot get fuel.
content: Fuel shortages in the Gaza Strip have grown so dire that the U.N. agency that has helped feed, school and shelter Palestinians there for decades said Wednesday that it might have to start shutting down operations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Bush’s Institute Issues an Urgent Plea for Congress to Renew His AIDS Program
description: PEPFAR, created by President George W. Bush in 2003 to combat the disease, faces an uncertain future now that its authorizing legislation has lapsed.
content: The institute founded by President George W. Bush issued an urgent call on Wednesday for Congress to renew the global AIDS program known as PEPFAR, a centerpiece of Mr. Bush’s foreign policy legacy that has become a victim of abortion politics on Capitol Hill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: New Jersey Governor Joins School Halloween Fray: ‘Give Me a Break’
description: The South Orange and Maplewood school district tried to help students who felt left out on Halloween. The governor’s response: “Seriously?”
content: If you happen to attend one of the 10 schools in New Jersey’s South Orange and Maplewood school district, put away that Spiderman costume on Halloween. Or wait until after school.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aileen Jacobson
title: City Island: A ‘Little Magical Wonderland’ in the Bronx
description: This 1.5-mile-long island, with “a beach on almost every block,” may feel like small-town New England, but it’s part of the city.
content: When Wendy Yang Clark first arrived on City Island, a place she had never heard of, it was early-morning dark. A costume designer, she was there to work on the HBO series “Boardwalk Empire” in this narrow, 1.5-mile-long section of the Bronx.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Those Doritos Too Expensive? Stores Offer Their Own Version.
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, October 25, 2023.
content: “If you’re going to sell a store-branded apple cinnamon ice cream, it had better be the best apple cinnamon ice cream you’ve ever had.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Women Will Vote at a Vatican Meeting for the First Time
description: Some women participating in a conference on sensitive church issues said they feel heartened by the discussions taking place, though change may remain slow.
content: When Helena Jeppesen-Spuhler, an advocate for the ordination of women, joined a major Vatican meeting this month, she was skeptical that an institution dominated by men for 2,000 years was ready to listen to women like her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova
title: As Ukraine War Grinds On, Widows Try to See Life After Loss
description: Support groups formed to help thousands of new widows see a dual role in healing their nation. “Our society was not ready to face such scale of grief,” one widow said.
content: Maria and her husband, Artem, dreamed of visiting the Grand Canyon. Alyona and Ilya fantasized about building a bar, with a stage for local musicians. Yulia and Oleksandr talked about taking a road trip in the mountains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins
title: The Speakership Is Yours, Mike Johnson. Good Luck With That.
description: This House is certainly not ... homey.
content: That House speaker mess was all Donald Trump’s fault. Yeah, yeah, I know you’re not going to argue with me if I blame him for something bad. (“Saturday night’s block party was canceled because of the threat of rain and … Donald Trump.”) Still, follow this thought.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein, David Yaffe-Bellany and J. Edward Moreno
title: The Challenges Facing Sam Bankman-Fried’s Lawyers
description: They are set to start their defense on Thursday, with the FTX founder planning to testify in his criminal fraud trial. Hurdles include what Mr. Bankman-Fried’s former associates said on the stand.
content: On the second day of Sam Bankman-Fried’s fraud trial this month, one of the lawyers for the cryptocurrency mogul delivered an emphatic message to the jury. Mr. Bankman-Fried is not a criminal, the lawyer declared, and every decision that led to the collapse of his FTX crypto exchange had been made in “good faith.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Roy
title: The Taylor and Travis Fan Fiction That’s Tearing TikTok Apart
description: “Roughing the Princess,” an erotic e-book inspired by an actual relationship, veered too close to reality for many of Taylor Swift’s fans.
content: She’s a beloved blonde pop star with the initials T.S. He’s a handsome N.F.L. player with a popular podcast and the initials T.K. Together, they have fused America’s obsession with pop stars and athletes into a celebrity pairing so incandescent it’s almost celestial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Steve Eder
title: Johnson Played Leading Role in Effort to Overturn 2020 Election
description: Representative Mike Johnson recruited House Republicans to back a lawsuit to overturn the results, and he was a key architect of his party’s objections to certifying President Biden’s victory.
content: If Representative Jim Jordan of Ohio was the most prominent public face of the congressional effort to fight the results of the 2020 election, his mentee, the newly elected Speaker Mike Johnson of Louisiana, was a silent but pivotal partner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: My Son Poses a Threat to My Safety. Should I Evict Him?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether parental responsibility should outweigh a person’s well-being.
content: I’m a nearly 70-year-old single mother living with an adult son of 40 who has schizoaffective disorder, which is a combination of schizophrenia and bipolar conditions. I testified at a juried trial that for over 10 years he has been averse to staying on antipsychotic meds, and that, as a result, he has been jailed, and that he has attacked me repeatedly in outbursts of rage. But two of 12 jurors didn’t agree that my son should be obliged to stay on meds. As a result, he has just been released from a medication mandate. Now, for the umpteenth time, distant family members are urging me to boot my mentally disabled son out of the apartment we share.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Living In ... City Island, the Bronx
description: This 1.5-mile-long island has “a beach on almost every block” and a close community. But while it feels like small-town New England, it’s not.
content: This 1.5-mile-long island has “a beach on almost every block” and a close community. But while it feels like small-town New England, it’s not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Republicans Nominate Louisiana’s Mike Johnson for House Speaker
description: Representative Mike Johnson of Louisiana was nominated for speaker in a secret-ballot vote by his peers, hours after Representative Tom Emmer of Minnesota withdrew his bid in the face of swift party backlash.
content: Representative Mike Johnson of Louisiana was nominated for speaker in a secret-ballot vote by his peers, hours after Representative Tom Emmer of Minnesota withdrew his bid in the face of swift party backlash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Biden Supports Israel and Calls for More Aid for Gaza
description: During a news conference with the Australian prime minister, President Biden reiterated his support for Israel while stressing the need to ensure that humanitarian assistance reaches civilians in Gaza.
content: During a news conference with the Australian prime minister, President Biden reiterated his support for Israel while stressing the need to ensure that humanitarian assistance reaches civilians in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Goldbaum, Alex Kingsbury and Alexander Stockton
title: Pick a Side. Pick a Side. Pick a Side. Now.
description: Social media demands that you’re with us or against us.
content: Social media demands that you’re with us or against us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nailah Morgan
title: Hurricane Otis Wreaks Havoc On Mexican Resort City
description: Strong winds damaged resorts along the coast of Acapulco, Mexico, near where Otis made landfall.
content: Strong winds damaged resorts along the coast of Acapulco, Mexico, near where Otis made landfall.
source.name: The New York Times
